scenes.location: LANDING STRIP 35, ROGERS DRY LAKE BED, EAFB
characters: INIT. MULTI-AXIS TRAINER ROOM, LEWIS FLIGHT CENTER
THE COCKPIT WITH NEIL FOR THIS ENTIRE HEART-POUNDING RIDE
EXIT. ASTRONAUT CREW QUARTERS, CAPE CANAVERAL
BACK EVEN FURTHER ON THE OTHER SIDE
116, 117, 118... THE SKY TURNS FROM BLUE TO A CHILLING BL
PLANE IS ROCKETING TOWARDS A TALL NASA BUILDING
NOSE IS STICKING STRAIGHT UP IN THE AIR
FLAMING THRUST RIPPING THE TWO STAGES APART

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of BLUE EYES. TICKING back and forth. Rapidly. We' knocked out by this FIRST IMAGE, by the eyes, oblivious t RAW and FRIGHTENING WALL OF SOUND all around us.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Data check? NEIL (0.C.) 2 APU on. Cabin pressure is good, 3500 on #1, 3355 on #2. Platform internal power. PULL BACK TO FIND NEIL ARMSTRONG, 31, in a silver pressur and helmet. Neil is INTENSE and INTENSELY FOCUSED, impres given the SEVERE TURBULENCE that bangs him around the coc

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: What’s your mixing chambers? NEIL (INTO COMMS) -44 and -45.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Two minute point. NEIL (INTO COMMS) MH circuit breakers on... Neil flips a switch on the low tech console. He glances u from the analogue dials and out the cockpit window... and the plane looks like a ROCKET, it’s ‘cause it is. This is the X-15. And as we're about to see, it's the FAS FUCKING AIRCRAFT EVER MADE. But just now, it isn't flying... or rather, not flying al Neil’s X-15 is attached to the wing of a B-52 -- BALLS 8, four engine BEHEMOTH that’s shaking even more than the X- It's more than a bit terrifying, but Neil calmly hits ano switch as he’s KNOCKED across the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Protocol is off. Little bumpy. It’s classic Armstrong understatement; underscored as we the B-52 pilot (BUTCH) TOSSED against the window of his p

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Worst it's ever been, real rough up here, fluctuating a half degree each side. This just drives Neil into deeper focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Velocity 900 fps, altitude JOE (COMMS) 44,500, pitch attitude level. Copy. Neil, we're reading your heart rate at 145. No reply. Neil’s eyes TICK METHODICALLY from gauge to gau

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Neil, we’re reading your heart rate at 145, do you copy?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Copy Joe. Igniter ready to light. Neil’s not gonna engage. Whatever adrenaline spike his bo is experiencing, Neil’s determined to remain detached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. We can almost hear JOE WALKER, on the other end o the comms, debating whether to abort. At last, he relents

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Okay. Arm switch lite NEIL (INTO COMMS) checks. Going to prime. Ammonia up. In the bumpy cockpit, Neil springs back into action.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Twenty seconds to drop -- Rog, precool on, lox pump bearing plus eight.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Ten seconds -- Igniter idle, ready to launch on 3, 2, 1, release... Suddenly the X-15 is RELEASED from the wing of the B-52. Through the cockpit window, we see the B-52 RISE SHARPLY the X-15 DROPS IN FREE FALL... A FREE FALL we feel in our gut because WE’RE NOT CUTTING And if you haven’t figured it out by now, WE’RE GONNA BE

dialogues.speaker: THE COCKPIT WITH NEIL FOR THIS ENTIRE HEART-POUNDING RIDE
dialogues.text: So. We’re DROPPING. FAST. Neil PUNCHES the igniter... the rocket LIGHTS and WE HEAR THE ROAR OF 57,000 POUNDS OF TH

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: And I got a good lite and aw... The words are literally left behind and Neil’s THROWN bac into his seat as the rocket TAKES OFF at a VIOLENT RATE. FIGHTS OFF 6 G’s, reaching for the stick.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Roll. He tilts the stick slightly and the plane BUCKS TO THE R TOSSING Neil like a RAG DOLL and TAKING OUR BREATH AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (FAINT, COMMS)
dialogues.text: Good on track, 15 seconds. NEIL (INTO COMMS) Pulling up, I’m indicating Mach 3. Neil pulls on the stick and RISES SHARPLY towards the hea He’s PRESSED into his seat and we see the plane’s blue ni nose, glowing CHERRY RED from the heat. Sweet Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (FAINTER, COMMS)
dialogues.text: Seem to be a tad steep. NEIL (INTO COMMS) Okay, I’m... Neil’s eyes TICK to the altitude gauge, SPINNING UP past 150,000 feet. He makes an adjustment as the X-15 PUSHES THROUGH THE HORIZON, BLUE SKY NOW TURNING TO BLACK...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: I’m indicating 5,800, pushing over. Yes, that's Mach 5.8, almost 4,000 mph, and we feel every of it... ‘til we pass 170,000 feet and Neil CUTS THE ENGI ..-JOLTING him against his harness... and INTO MICROGRAVI For a moment all is STILL. Quiet. We hear a BUZZ over the radio, but it's GARBLED. Far away.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: 190,000 feet, no radio reception, setting instruments to record high altitude flight response. Neil punches a few buttons as A LOGBOOK FLOATS PAST HIM.. because WE’RE SUBORBITAL, high as the first Mercury fligh So yeah, things float. Oh, and the view is pretty good to Neil looks out, takes in the earth stretching, curving aw below the BLACK SKY. The STARS. The MOON.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: 207,000 feet. Top view, looking out, can see an awful long ways. Everything is quiet save for the low purr of the APUs. Ne turns his attention to the G-LIMITER GAUGE as the X-15 sl falls back to earth, the altitude gauge starting to spin. The plane SHAKES, but Neil stays focused on the G-limiter creeping towards 2.5 G's. Which is when we hear it...  An ODD SOUND. A MECHANICAL WHINE. It seems out of place. Neil ignores it as gravity takes hold, PRESSING him forwa against his seat straps. We hear GARBLED BUZZ over comms.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Still no radio. 150,000 feet, little shake in the yaw. Again, Armstrong understatement... the plane SHAKES VIOLE as the altitude gauge spins down past 120,000, the BLACK FADING BACK TO BLUE as we fall back into the atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (FAINT, COMMS)
dialogues.text: Okay, brakes out, check the RCS off. WIND WHIPS over the plane. Neil reduces his angle of atta still focused on the G-Limiter, still ignoring that ODD W

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: RCS off, brakes are out, G- JOE (COMMS) Limiter not quite at 5 G’s. Okay, 25° stabilizer, hard deft turn. Neil pulls on the stick, eyes FIXED on the G-limiter, FAI TO NOTICE the plane isn’t turning... that the altitude ga is HOLDING at 115,000 FEET. Slowly, it begins to CLIMB...

dialogues.speaker: 116, 117, 118... THE SKY TURNS FROM BLUE TO A CHILLING BL
dialogues.text: The shaking STOPS, the whipping wind FADES to EERIE SILEN

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: We show you ballooning, not turning. The comms are drowned out by the ODD WHINE. Neil, FIXATED the G-limiter, doesn’t see the altitude gauge FLIPPING UP

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Lot more left there. Neil! Joe's voice cuts through the whine, which FADES. Neil BLI noticing how QUIET it is... the plane has stopped shaking Neil’s eyes TICK from the black sky to the altitude gauge 120, 121, 122... SHIT. He realizes he’s fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Rog, I’m reading -- You're bouncing off the atmosphere, hard left! Neil YANKS on the stick, eyes DARTING from the dynamic pressure gauge to the vista sailing by below.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Aerodynamic controls not responding. Unlike Joe, Neil remains calm... but as we PUSH IN ON HI ticking from gauge to gauge, we see the INTENSITY, the FO

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Switching over to reaction controls. Neil drops the stick, grabs the ballistic controls. We he HISS as a BURST of peroxide gas SHOOTS OUT from the nose the plane and Neil's TOSSED BACK in his seat... ...the plane’s nose FLYING UP TOWARDS THE SKY, the horizo ABOVE Neil’s head; the black sky, the stars, BELOW his fe And we realize... NEIL'S FLIPPED THE X-15 ON ITS BACK, TH

dialogues.speaker: NOSE IS STICKING STRAIGHT UP IN THE AIR
dialogues.text: The canopy view is crazy, mountains above, sky below, the world upside down, but Neil keeps his eyes on the ALTITUD GAUGE, inching up. 123, 124... then HOLDING at 125,000 FE A beat... then it begins to DROP. 123, 120, 115, 105... The sky once again FADES TO BLUE and we hear a SLIGHT WIN under the plane. Neil's eyes TICK from the altitude gauge the dynamic pressure gauge...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Surface pressure rising, switch over to aerodynamic controls. Neil reaches for the stick... but the atmosphere GRABS TH PLANE, PULLING IT DOWN ON ITS BACK! FUCK! Neil STRAINS to hold on as he's THROWN around the cockpit with 9 G'S OF F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The altitude gauge SPINS down at TERRIFYING SPEED. 95, 90 85... Shit. Neil STRUGGLES, WRESTLING with the stick... u he manages to FLIP the lifeless plane RIGHT-SIDE UP. Jesu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Neil points the plane towards Edwards, the RADIO SQUAW

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Neil, can you give us a visual estimate of your location? Neil scans the landscape, searching for the desert runway the plane DIVES LIKE A BRICK towards the mountains...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Looks like I’m pretty... in pretty bad shape for the south lake bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Okay, working the contingencies for a landing from the south. Neil’s eyes TICK over the horizon, but he knows what’s c

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Neil, there is no contingency. You need to get back to Rogers. Neil BEARS DOWN, trying to GLIDE the engine-less plane fa than ever. Yes, the X-15 was BUILT to land without power. but generally, a pilot had A_LOT more altitude to work wi The plane SHIMMIES back and forth, wind HOWLING at 300 kn

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: I can see the base, runway 35, it’1l have to be a straight in approach. His eyes DART from the distant desert landing strip to th altitude gauge, dropping 20,000 feet per minute. Neil FLI his head bumper... and SMOKE POURS from the instrument pa

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Can we get a visual estimate? The cockpit is FILLED with smoke...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: ...pretty hard to tell from here... Neil hits a button. WHOOSH! The plane dumps peroxide and smoke clears the cabin, but the view is HARDLY A RELIEF..

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: I’m a little shorter than I thought. Neil pulls the stick to hold altitude, but he keeps DROPP 9,000... 8500... 8000 feet... Fuck. It's going to be clos We see Butch’s B-52 SWING UP on Neil’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Your ventral is still on! Neil REACTS, ANNOYED at himself. He HITS the ventral butt The ventral fin BLOWS OFF and the plane PITCHES forward.. Neil STRUGGLES with the stick... 4,000, 3,500, 3,000 feet

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Start your flaps down now! Neil PUNCHES the flaps. The plane BUCKS UP, reaching towa the runway... and now the ODD MECHANICAL WHINE returns. PUSH IN on Neil, INTENSITY BURNING as the whine CRESCEND 2,000, 1,000, 500 feet... the plane HURTLES past the edge the brush, JUST CLEARING THE JOSHUA TREES!!!

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: You’re in! Go head and put her down! Neil PULLS UP HARD, flaring the plane, nose up, skids dow The plane SLAMS DOWN with a BANG. It SKIDS ROUGHLY across desert... SHAKING VIOLENTLY... And just as we think it mi BREAK into a million pieces, Neil HITS the back fin brake The plane goes into a CONTROLLED SLIDE... kicking up a HU CLOUD of dust... and TOSSING NEIL ACROSS THE COCKPIT... u at last, the plane eases to a HALT. For a moment, all is STILL. Silent. Then Neil STIRS... le forward and takes his helmet off.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: I’m down.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! (clearly relieved) Very nice, Neil. Posse will get there shortly. As the dust clears and Neil looks out towards the fire tr in the distance rolling towards him, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Air Force jeep WIPES FRAME... REVEALING EDWARDS AFB FI TRUCKS, NASA PICK UPS and TECHS surrounding Neil’s X-15. period cars are cool, but our eye is drawn to the x-15. It's our first real look at the hypersonic rocket plane. long fuselage, the thick dorsal wedge fin, the NASA signa It's every bit as awesome as the flight we just witnessed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN on THE OPEN COCKPIT. NASA Engineers take readings the instrument panel while Neil makes notes in his logboo beat, then Neil finishes up and climbs out of the cockpit

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Think you set a couple records. A FAMILIAR VOICE. ‘Butch’ Butchart, 30s, flight gear, wal up with Neil’s boss, Joe Walker, 40, thoughtful. Butch GR Neil nods stiffly as a TECH with a MAP calls out.  10.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Butch, you mind walking me through the release data? Butch heads off. Joe turns to Neil.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I don’t think anyone's experienced that kind of atmosphere bounce, we should try to replicate it in the sim --

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Neil.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Joe looks at him, concerned. But Neil’s not going there. FLIGHT SURGEON who’s been waiting by the plane intercedes

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT SURGEON
dialogues.text: Hey Joe, I gotta do his work up. Joe nods. Neil follows the surgeon off. Joe turns back to his jeep, only to find a grizzled AIR FORCE COLONEL, late

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL YEAGER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Kid’s a good engineer, but he’s not too good an airplane driver. Bouncing up in the thin air where you can’t turn, it’s not too bright.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He was focused on the G-limiter. It was a core flight objective. But it’s not clear Joe believes that. The Colonel’s tag GLINTS in the sun. C. YEAGER.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL YEAGER
dialogues.text: Three mishaps in three months. It’s not my call, but I’d ground him. Yeager heads out. As we HOLD ON Joe, wondering if Yeager’ right, we hear it again... that ODD MECHANICAL WHINE... t same unnerving sound Neil heard in the X-15. It takes us

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a 2-year-old girl (KAREN). Quiet, self-contained  11. PULL BACK to see a COBALT RADIATION MACHINE HULKING over The source of the now familiar WHINE, it beams GAMMA RAYS her brain as she lies on a gurney. HOLD for an AWFUL BEAT... then REVERSE TO the OBSERVATION WINDOW. Neil and his wife, JANET, 27. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet BLINKS back tears, reaches for Neil... He takes her hand, but he’s focused on the nearby INSTRUM PANEL... his ever alert eyes TICKING across the console a TECH adjusts RADIATION LEVELS, sets the dials... 1.17. 1. Neil slips his hand out of Janet’s, pulls out a LOGBOOK t down the numbers... all while trying to block out that SO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON Neil as the WHINE CRESCENDOES. Relentless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUIET. Janet on the floor outside Karen's bedroom, her so RICK, 4, asleep in her lap. In SOFT B/G, Neil SINGS softl Karen, then kisses her forehead... HOLD ON Janet trying to keep it together as Neil walks ou

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I‘11l put him down. Janet nods. Exhausted. Neil tousles her hair then gathers Rick in his arms. As he carries Rick off, CUT TO-- INT. RICK’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil tucks Rick in, METHODICALLY straightens the sheets. spots a mess of an unfinished model plane on the desk. Ne COMPULSIVELY moves to tidy it up... then pauses. And SITS ..-in the half light, he glues on a wing and gently blows dry. The precision is calming. He’d keep at it, but the doorbell RINGS. Reluctantly, Neil stands and we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil leads Joe Walker in. Joe carries in a casserole.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Can I offer you a beer?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sure.  12.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (off the casserole) That wasn’t necessary.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Can’t imagine Janet’s been up to much cooking. No. Neil hands Joe a beer. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How’s Karen?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: She's doing fine. Neil doesn't want to talk about it. An awkward beat. Then

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dick Day called from Houston, Bob Gilruth was asking after you.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: For Gemini? Joe nods. Neil’s eyes TICK to the NASA X-Press newsletter a pile of mail on the table. NASA To Select More Astronau

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I told them it’s probably not the right time.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Gemini and Apollo are speculative. We're up as high as the Mercury flights, not sure why I’d leave now. Joe clocks the emotional DENIAL, but doesn’t comment on i

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well. It’1ll be nice to keep you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small space. A desk, some shelves. A light CLICKS ON. Neil walks down the stairs, over to the desk. He sits. We now see neatly stacked MEDICAL BOOKS, mimeographed cop of scientific RESEARCH PAPERS. All marked and tabbed. Neil opens a LARGE COMPUTATIONAL NOTEBOOK filled with TID NOTES. He writes Cobalt Session No.2... then pulls out hi logbook. He transfers the radiation levels. 1.17. 1.33.  13. A beat. He adds a new heading. Side Effects. Neil pauses. Then... Fatigue. Dizziness. Extreme headache. Vomiting (repeated). Hair loss/Scalp irritation. Loss of appetite. Neil stops writing. He scans the list, then grabs a stack papers on COBALT THERAPY and TUCKS them into a MANILA FOL that he places on a shelf. Beside a DOZEN other folders. Neil takes a breath, then reaches for a dog-eared researc paper from Johns Hopkins. Pre-Adolescent Glioma of the Po Experimental Treatments & Therapies. It’s WELL-MARKED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil's clearly read it a_hundred times. Yet he picks up a high-lighter and starts to read. Again. DETERMINED. Off Neil, we PRELAP the chilling sound of a MECHANICAL CR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a CRANK. Turning. Lowering a small coffin. TIGHT ON Neil with Janet and their son, Rick. All in blac Janet and Rick cry as KAREN’S COFFIN sinks. Neil does not He's impassive... but he HUGS his family CLOSE. TIGHT. The SOUND of the crank takes us to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG PUSH IN over trays of food. Dark suits and dresses Quiet murmurs. No laughter or smiles, no pleasant small t There is no pain like the loss of a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass Joe and his wife, huddled with Janet. Neil’s by t window nearby. Watching Rick toss a ball in the yard... BARELY ENDURING the condolences, the soft pats on the bac Just when it looks like Neil might break, he SLIPS AWAY. Winding through the crowd. Towards the basement door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The desk now a MESS. Marked up medical books and scattere papers. Neil's notebook, now FILLED, lies open. We hear the door. Neil walks down the stairs, moves to th desk. His eyes TICK over books... papers... the notebook. A beat, then Neil closes the NOTEBOOK... slowly pulls tog the PAPERS and the BOOKS... ...-and, up on a high shelf, carefully STACKS THEM ALL AW  14. Neil’s eyes TICK over the EMPTY DESK. Then he turns off t light. And exits. We HOLD on the shelf, then CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a WESTCLOX ELECTRIC ALARM CLOCK, hour hand near A beat, then we PAN over to Neil. Staring up at the ceili Wide awake. The alarm TRILLS. Neil turns it off as Janet stirs. Groggy, she rolls over, reaching for him.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Neil? But he's already gone. Off Janet, ALONE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, Butch and another pilot enter, coats and coffee. Jaw laughing... until they spot Neil. Working at his desk. The men PAUSE, AWKWARD. SURPRISED to see him. BUTCH (CONT’D) PILOT Hey, Neil. Neil.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Hey. Butch, you have time to talk through the data on the bounce?

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: ...sure, yeah, of course. Lemme just put my things down. Butch and the other pilot head to their desks. Joe leans

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You can take a few days, you know.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I know. Joe sees he’s not going anywhere, starts to head off when

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me. Butch clutches a XEROXED MEMO. He holds it up. A DIAGRAM a strange, spider-like contraption, a cockpit on top.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: They want a free flying trainer to simulate a moon landing... how the hell are we gonna do that?  15.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I think that’s the question.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: They haven't even figured out how to get to the moon. I’m not wasting time on impossible problems. Butch tosses the memo, exits. As Joe goes after him, Neil GLANCES at the memo, contemplating the challenge. His eye TICK over the DIAGRAM, curious, absorbed... alive. A beat, then Neil REACHES for the memo and we SMASH TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a SYRINGE pumping water into a MAN'S EAR. Astronaut Selection, Project Gemini August 13, 1962 The syringe empties. A TECH dips it in a bucket of ICE WA refills it and turns back to... Neil. In his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Tell us when you want to stop. Neil eyes a SECOND TECH with a stopwatch as the WHOOSH of water in his ear propels us into a SERIES OF SHORT SCENES

dialogues.speaker: ISOLATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Two TECHS walk Neil into the empty, windowless room.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Come out after two hours. They leave and close the door. The lights flick off. It's PITCH BLACK. Silent. A beat. Then we hear Neil hum.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Three hundred and sixty men in a boarding house bed, roll over, roll over. One turned over and the other man said, roll over, roll over...

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEW ROOM
dialogues.text: A STACK of 'TESTS' is dropped on a desk in front of Neil. eyes the first test. For each of the paired statements be select the statement that best fits your personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil digs in: (1) I worry a lot about things in the futur that could go wrong; (2) It takes a lot for me to get ang  16. A beat. Neil circles NUMBER TWO and moves on...

dialogues.speaker: EXAM ROOM TWO
dialogues.text: A foot PLUNGES into an ICE BATH.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Take it out when it’s too cold. A tech starts a stopwatch, watches Neil. Who settles in.

dialogues.speaker: ISOLATION ROOM, (PITCH BLACK)
dialogues.text: We see nothing, hear nothing... but Neil.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Two hundred three men in a boarding house bed, roll over, roll over...

dialogues.speaker: EXAM ROOM ONE
dialogues.text: More ice water shoots into Neil's ear. The tech nearby glances at his stopwatch. Neil’s jaw sets.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEW ROOM
dialogues.text: A last pair: (1) I like to help friends when they’re in trouble; (2) I like to do my best in whatever I undertake Neil reads, thinks and circles NUMBER TWO. Then he puts t test aside and reaches for the next one. Draw a picture of yourself. A beat. As Neil starts to dra

dialogues.speaker: EXAM ROOM TWO
dialogues.text: Neil's foot in an ice-bath. Turning WHITE. The tech with stopwatch jots down a note. Neil doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEW ROOM
dialogues.text: Neil finishes a fairly generic stick figure drawing of himself. He turns the page. Draw a picture of your family Neil HARDENS. As he STARES at the blank page, we CUT TO -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: .--but in the struggle, his neck got broke, roll over, roll... Neil trails off. A LONG BEAT. We feel him STRUGGLING. The just when we think he might to break...  17.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Eighty nine men in a boarding house bed, roll over, roll over...

dialogues.speaker: EXAM ROOM TWO
dialogues.text: Neil's foot in an ice bath. Now BLUE. Neil bears down.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ...he turned over and no one said roll over, roll over...

dialogues.speaker: EXAM ROOM ONE
dialogues.text: WHOOSH... The tech unloads another syringe into Neil's ea PUSH IN on Neil, blank, NUMB. And as we go TIGHT ON HIS E we see it again. The pain there. The deep, deep PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The last man thought it'd be a great joke, to keep on rolling when...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ...not a soul spoke, but he fell on the floor and his neck got broke, roll over, roll over. Neil BANGS on the door. It opens, the light JARRING. Neil blinks, then walks out. He follows a tech down the hall.. but we HOLD ON a MAN in a tie and shirtsleeves. Meet DEKE SLAYTON, 37, slightly gray, MACHO back when tha appealing. Deke turns to the tech with the stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE SLAYTON
dialogues.text: How long? The tech shows Deke the watch. 2:03.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall lined with chairs, candidates reading PROJECT GE briefing books. FIND Neil looking for a seat... when PETE CONRAD, 32, a wicked witted wasp from Princeton calls out

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: Air Force? Navy? ...Leatherneck? Neil looks at him, BLANK.

dialogues.speaker: ED WHITE
dialogues.text: Christ, another egghead.  18. Pete SMIRKS, trades a look with ED WHITE, 32, a lanky Tex with easy-going charm. But Neil doesn’t engage. Instead, heads to the end of the hall, finds a seat and opens a pa

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Civilian? Neil glances at ELLIOT SEE, 35, a flight test engineer fr UCLA, older than the rest. And more cerebral. Neil nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Me too. Elliot See.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Neil Armstrong. Neil turns to his packet, but Elliot, anxious, keeps talk

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Tough morning, huh? I barely lasted two minutes in the ice bath. I saw one of the military guys keep his foot in so long it turned blue.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I think NASA’s more interested in psychological reactions than physiological performance.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: I just figured he probably didn’t do so well on the intelligence tests. This draws a smile, maybe the first we’ve seen from Neil. SMALL CONNECTION. Which for Neil is no little thing.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Armstrong. Neil looks up. Deke stands by the door at the end of the hall, a candidate slipping out behind him. Neil stands.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty chair in front of A PANEL OF MEN, including Bob Gilruth, 48, who’s voice we heard earlier. In person, Gil is tall, hawkish and as commanding as he sounded at the t Deke leads Neil in, introduces him.  19.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, Neil Armstrong. Neil, you know Bob Gilruth, Head of the Manned Space Center; Chris Kraft, our flight director; and we asked John Glenn to sit in. I figure you watched his flight with the rest of the country. If Neil's impressed he doesn’t show it. He shakes hands w Gilruth; CHRIS KRAFT, 37, looks like a 50s ad rep; and JO GLENN, 40, clean cut, very much the American hero. Glenn smiles as Neil sits in front of the panel.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN GLENN
dialogues.text: Deke said you flew for the Navy in Korea. Panther, right?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Yes, Neil was a Navy combat pilot. And if you’re surprise didn’t mention that in the hall, you’re not paying attent

dialogues.speaker: JOHN GLENN
dialogues.text: Good lateral control, but pretty stiff in pitch, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Never bothered me much.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN GLENN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, I didn’t fly as many missions as you. But I bet I took more flak. Glenn warm, smiles; Neil doesn’t. Awkward. Gilruth jumps

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: Neil, we've been chatting with candidates about the program so we can get an idea of how everyone thinks. Now, as I’m sure you know, our decision to forego Direct Ascent in favor of Lunar-Orbit Rendezvous has had a major impact on Gemini.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS KRAFT
dialogues.text: Do you have any thoughts on that decision, Neil?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I think it was a good decision.  20. An awkward pause. A beat. The

dialogues.speaker: JOHN GLENN
dialogues.text: Would you care to elaborate on that?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Even taking Von Braun’s initial criticism into account, the payload saved by parking the primary vehicle in lunar orbit seems well worth the resulting challenges.

dialogues.speaker: KRAFT
dialogues.text: What do you see as the challenges?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (considers) Cislunar navigation for one. You're aiming for a narrower target, inserting a craft into lunar orbit. Of course, you’d also need to design the smaller lunar excursion ship and figure out how to land it. panel waits. Deke prompts Neil.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Is that all, Neil?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: .--well, the most difficult hurdles would be rendezvous and docking. But that’s only assuming you want to get the men back. Is he serious? A beat, then Glenn LAUGHS. The room follows suit, laughing hard, assuming Neil was joking. Of course, it’s not clear that he was.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Does anyone have anything else?

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: Yes. Neil, I was very sorry to hear about your daughter. Neil nods, impassive.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What’s the question?

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: Well... how’s your wife?  21.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I think she’s handling it well. Off Gilruth, satisfied with Neil’s answer, we SMASH TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, Jan and Rick eat supper. Deathly quiet, a PALLOR ha

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Can I go play outside?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Just stay in the backyard where we can see you. Rick scurries off. Neil barely notices. A PAINFUL beat... it’s a relief when the phone RINGS. Janet gets up, answer

dialogues.speaker: JANET, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, one second. Neil? Neil looks up. Janet holds out the phone. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is Neil. Yes. Uh huh. Okay. Yes, sir. Thank you. Neil hangs up. Processing. Then he sees Janet STARING.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I got it. He looks unsure. So does Janet, but she buries her qualms

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It’s a fresh start.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It’ll be an adventure. He looks out the window at the night sky, UNRESPONSIVE. J PULLS HIM to her, trying to bridge the divide. Out of hab Neil wraps his arms around her, but his eyes remain LOCKE the sky. Off his focused gaze, we -- FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAINY FOOTAGE of the Russian cosmonaut program. Two Vost capsules blasting off, one after the next...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT WELSH, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Two weeks ago, the Soviets put two manned spacecraft in orbit. PULL BACK to find NEIL in the flickering light. He sits a small desk, taking COPIOUS NOTES as CIA AGENT JOHN WELSH narrates from beside the REEL-TO-REEL PROJECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT WELSH
dialogues.text: Vostok 3 and 4 were launched the same day and, at one point, orbited within 75 miles of each other. Near Neil, Elliot See looks GRIM, but Neil remains analyt as Welsh finishes and Deke flips on a VU-GRAPH PROJECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: The Soviets are ahead of us on rendezvous and everything else. Which would scare the hell out of me if I weren’t so pissed off. Resolute, Deke puts a transparency on the overhead and DR (yep, it’s 1962) two circles. He labels them (EARTH, MOON then SKETCHES a rocket flying from one to the other...

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: The rocket Von Braun’s building is big, it should get us to the moon. Course, a monkey could fly it. But to get to the surface and back... PUSH IN on Neil as Deke draws a SMALL SHIP flying from th rocket to the surface, then returning to the original cra

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: ...we’ll need men trained to catch another ship in orbit and dock. This is the primary mission of Project Gemini. Deke writes RENDEZVOUS. DOCKING. Neil, INTENT, takes it d

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Proving men can live in space for the week it will take to get to the moon and back, proving men can survive and work outside the space craft... these are secondary goals.  23. DURATION. EXTRA VEHICULAR ACTIVITY (E.V.A.). Neil’s eyes TICK from Deke to the screen to his notes, getting it dow

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Only if we master these tasks can we move on to Apollo and consider trying to land a man on the moon. Gilruth flicks on the lights, revealing the nine Gemini m including Ed White and Pete Conrad, who we met baiting Ne Now Ed and Pete look TENSE, as do the rest of the men. An like Neil and Elliot, they’ve all taken COPIOUS NOTES.

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: None of you need incentive. But this is very much a race --

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: And we're already more than a dick’s length behind the other guy.

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: ..-point is, the nine of you need to stay focused, despite the new pressures and the temptations that will invariably come your way.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: So anything we can eat, drink or screw within 24 hours, right? Ed and some of the other men smirk. Deke, Gilruth do NOT.

dialogues.speaker: ED WHITE
dialogues.text: We know the drill, we’re used to this kind of attention.

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: Due respect, Mr. White? You’re not. As he says this, we see something on Neil’s face we haven seen before. TREPIDATION. We hear a crowd ROAR and SMASH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 1,800 seat auditorium, filled to capacity. Introduction of NASA Astronaut Group 2 September 17, 1962 REPORTERS and CAMERA CREWS from the three major networks, major radio broadcasting systems, the wire services and d of domestic and international newspapers and magazines.  24.

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH, (0.C., ON LOUDSPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Neil A. Armstrong. Frank F. Borman, Jr. Charles ‘Pete’ Conrad... ON STAGE, Deke is with Gilruth, who introduces the astron They walk out, all in blue suits save Conrad, in white li

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH, (ON LOUDSPEAKER)
dialogues.text: James A. Lovell. James A. McDivitt. Elliot M. See. Thomas P. Stafford. Edward H. White, II. John W. Young. These are The New Nine. This is Project Gemini. The crowd applauds, dozens of flashbulbs POP. TIGHT ON Ne a smile frozen on his face, eyes DARTING every which way. NEIL’S POV. In BLURRED CUTS: flashbulbs; press; the crowd astronauts waving; Rick and Janet (pregnant)... It's DIZZ

dialogues.speaker: GILRUTH
dialogues.text: We'll open it up for questions now. Gilruth points and a man from the AP stands.

dialogues.speaker: AP REPORTER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, what drew you to apply for the job? We go down the line, the men are RELAXED. QUICK, CUTTY --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BORMAN
dialogues.text: I like to be on the first team.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: I wanted to be a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: I feel this is the most important thing I could possibly do.

dialogues.speaker: ED WHITE
dialogues.text: I felt I had something to give to the program. ON THE AP GUY, scribbling. A beat, then he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: AP REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Armstrong? WHIP TO NEIL, UNCOMFORTABLE as we've seen. Halting, STIFF  25.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: It was the general challenge of... the unknowns of the program... and the general alignment of this part of it with our national goals. The men glance over. Elliot CLOCKS Neil’s discomfort. The

dialogues.speaker: JOHN YOUNG
dialogues.text: I agree with those other guys. As the crowd dissolves into laughter, FLASHBULBS TAKE US

dialogues.speaker: NASA ANNOUNCER, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: T minus one minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gemini nine STARE OUT into the distance. Beside them, GRANDSTAND of a few hundred people and THREE NETWORK CAME

dialogues.speaker: ED WHITE
dialogues.text: I thought it’d be bigger. We follow Ed’s gaze across two hundred yards of dirt toa small, orange scaffold holding up a THIN, RED-TIPPED ROCK Mercury 8 Launch, Cape Canaveral October 3, 1962 At 90 feet tall, 5 feet in diameter, the rocket’s much sm than the Saturn to come. And clearly much less sophistica

dialogues.speaker: NASA ANNOUNCER, (LOUDSPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds. PETE CONRAD Hard to believe Wally even fits on top of that thing. The men stare, SOBER, shaken by the fact that soon they’1 atop a rocket like this. PAN SLOWLY over their ANXIOUS FA

dialogues.speaker: NASA ANNOUNCER, (LOUDSPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Fifteen. Elliot See, Ed White... even Pete Conrad is nervous, fing crossed on both hands...

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER
dialogues.text: Ten. As the countdown begins in earnest we FIND NEIL. In contr to the others, Neil is TOTALLY CALM.  26.
HOLD ON Neil as the rocket DROWNS OUT the call, his face with the flame of 200,000 pounds of thrust...

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER
dialogues.text: Liftoff! Clock is started! And as we hear the rocket lift, we HOLD ON Neil, on the EMOTION in his eyes... a childlike look of WONDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a CBS NEWS BROADCAST. WALTER CRONKITE (in large earphones) at his desk. We see a chyron: CRISIS IN CUBA.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: If invasion is undertaken, the Russians have said that they would retaliate with rocket fire; we have said if there's rocket fire from Cuba we will retaliate and there goes the, uh, whole ballgame. PULL BACK to find JANET, PREGNANT, in a kitchen full of b No_longer unpacking. PALE, she stares at the B&W TV... wh the doorbell RINGS. She walks into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also full of boxes. Rick plays on the floor. Neil, on the couch, marks up a thick binder labeled GEMINI. ENGROSSED, doesn’t look up as Janet walks in and opens the door. Ed White stands with his WIFE PAT, 30.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Hey. Pat White, we live next door?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Of course. Hello. Janet Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: We only just moved in ourselves, but we've got a couple days on y’all... Pat holds out a Tupperware container of cookies.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Well, that’s awfully nice of you. Neil comes to the door with his binder. Ed’s uncomfortabl clearly this visit was Pat’s idea.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Hey Neil. We have an assignment?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: No. An awkward beat. Pat fills it.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I’ve just about got the kitchen squared. With everything going on in the news, company might be nice, I’ve already got some soup on...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Ed and I have an early flight out. Janet flushes, EMBARRASSED. And disappointed. But Pat doesn’t miss a beat.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes... you boys are heading to Cleveland, right? Assuming the world doesn’t end? She smiles at Janet. It almost sets Janet at ease.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Maybe another time?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, that’d be swell. It’s just so nice to meet y’all. Neil forces a smile back, then shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Pat stand there.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Told you. As they turn and head back towards their house, we CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: INIT. MULTI-AXIS TRAINER ROOM, LEWIS FLIGHT CENTER
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a familiar pair of blue eyes. Ticking to a pair hands BUCKLING straps... PULLING them tight.  28. FIND Neil in a cockpit chair, suspended within THREE CONCENTRIC STEEL RINGS. Welcome to the MULTI-AXIS TRAINER

dialogues.speaker: MULTI-AXIS SUPE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This replicates roll coupling on all three axis, the kind you might encounter in space. The SUPE nods to the hand controllers on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: MULTI-AXIS SUPE
dialogues.text: Trick is to take care of roll first, then pitch and yaw will be easier. Neil nods. The Supe starts the machine; the inner rings s tossing Neil in all directions. Slowly at first, then FAS PUSH IN on Neil. The chair speeds up, his head WHIPPING i and out of frame as he struggles to analyze the spin. His HANDS GRAB the controls... they CLICK several times.. the machine just spins FASTER. Neil bores down... but it’ fast, TOO FAST... His eyes droop... and we FADE TO GRAY.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: White, you’re up. Neil blinks, OPENS HIS EYES. The supe moves to unbuckle h

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I’m good. lLet’s go again. The Supe STARES. Then turns to Deke. Who shrugs. The othe astronauts watch, curious, as the Supe tightens Neil's st and starts the machine again. As it spins, we PUSH INTO - NEIL’S POV. The room, spinning. And if it’s nauseating, well, that's how it's supposed to feel. Neil CLICKS the controls and the trainer slows... only to FASTER. Shit. In BLURRED CUTS we see: the other ASTRONAUT FLASHBULBS; PRESS; a CROWD... and again we FADE TO GRAY.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Armstrong. Neil OPENS HIS EYES. Deke's bent over him.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Again. Deke’s SURPRISED. Ed White and a few others look ANNOYED, Deke responds to the look in Neil’s eyes. He nods to the Supe, who pulls Neil's straps tight and leans in, WHISPER

dialogues.speaker: MULTI-AXIS SUPE
dialogues.text: Use your inner ear. As Neil processes, the Supe steps back, starts up the mac NEIL'S POV. This time, as he spins, Neil CLOSES his eyes. THE SCREEN GOES DARK. But under the grating machine... WE HEAR the PULSE SLOSHING in Neil’s inner ear. Then the CLICK of the hand control. Again. And again... And as Nei opens his eyes, the machine SLOWS... And then STOPS. Elliot GAPES as the Supe unstraps Neil. N tries to stand, wobbles and falls... VOMITING all over. Ed looks UNIMPRESSED.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Serves him right.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Clean him up. White, strap in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil stands, bent over a sink. SHAKING. A beat, then he steadies himself and tries to stand up... to start DRY HEAVING. Again. And AGAIN. Spittle forming a the corners of his mouth. Neil finally gets it under control. Pale, he spits in the sink and splashes water on his face when... Ed walks in. the mirror, Neil sees Ed. Trying to look collected. But as Ed stands there, he turns GREEN. A beat, then... Ed RUSHES INTO a stall. We hear him VOMITING off screen. Neil, unimpressed himself, CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Elliot UPSIDE DOWN in a suit and helmet. Sweatin

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: You ready? REVEAL Pete Conrad, also upside down, in the other seat o Gemini trainer. Surprisingly serious. Elliot puts on a brave face, NODS. Conrad PULLS a handle the hatch doors under them SWING OPEN... WATER RUSHING IN As the men STRUGGLE to undo their harnesses, we CUT TO --  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil and the astronauts stand at the edge of a pool with TECHS, watching as the submerged capsule SHAKES in the wa

dialogues.speaker: EGRESS SUPE
dialogues.text: 15 seconds... 25 seconds... The EGRESS SUPE eyes his stopwatch. No one emerges. CONCE creeps across Neil's face... then Conrad surfaces, GASPIN

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: Piece of cake. Conrad sees the look on Neil’s face, REALIZES. And DIVES Elliot. Neil glances over at Deke, who doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: EGRESS SUPE
dialogues.text: 45 seconds... Neil STARES at the water. He can’t see what’s happening. eyes TICK from the rescue techs, to the Egress Supe, to D back to the water again. He scans it, his hand CLENCHING.

dialogues.speaker: EGRESS SUPE
dialogues.text: 60 seconds, Deke. At last, Deke nods to the rescue techs, who dive... just Conrad EMERGES with Elliot, SPUTTERING. Neil and others r down to pull him out of the pool as Deke jots down a NOTE

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Lovell, Armstrong, suit up. Neil hovers for a moment over Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Armstrong, get your ass in gear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NEIL in a low-tech capsule. STRAINING, his featu STRETCHED WIDE by the g forces. HOLD TIGHT on him, STRUGG to breathe, trying to muscle it out. SMASH TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil VOMITS beside the capsule, which is at the business of a MASSIVE CENTRIFUGE. PALE, Neil looks up as the next victim approaches... it’s Elliot. Elliot clocks how wrecked Neil is. And BLANCHES. SMASH TO  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, EXHAUSTED, collapses into a desk. As the other Gemi men sit, Neil opens the THICK BINDER in front of him. Physics of Rocket Propulsion - Rocket Vehicle Performance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: s A man in a suit (HAMMOCK) walks in, turns on the vu-graph

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOCK
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I’m David Hammock, I'11 be walking you through basic rocket physics. We’ll just cover the first chapter tonight. Neil flips through the chapter. It's 75 pages. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a wall clock. 10pm. A lone janitor mops the hall It’s QUIET... then the classroom door OPENS. Neil and the others stumble out, totally spent. They start to exit whe

dialogues.speaker: DEKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: A couple of you have been asking about assignments. Neil and the others turn. Deke and Kraft stand behind the The men are suddenly WIDE AWAKE.

dialogues.speaker: KRAFT
dialogues.text: The first missions will test basic functionality of the new capsule. We've made selections accordingly. You could hear a pin drop.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Back ups will train alongside primary crews for now. But there'll be plenty of flights for everyone. The list is outside my office. A beat. Then the men GRAB their packs and RUSH INTO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete leads the way, Ed and the others at his heels, crowd like high school kids around the LIST posted by Deke’s do  32.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BORMAN
dialogues.text: White, you lucky bastard. Ed inches forward. Smiles broadly. We see the list...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mission Prime Backup GT-3 Grissom-Young hirra-Stafford GT-4 MeDivitt-White Borman-Love GT-5 Cooper-Conrad Armstrong-See

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD
dialogues.text: Shit, I’m flying with Gordo? JIM LOVELL Punishment fits the crime... The men laugh as Neil walks out. Elliot turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: We're backup. Gemini 5.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Great. Unfazed, Neil exits with Elliot, not bothering to check t list. Ed clocks this, puzzled... not getting Neil at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil’s at the dinner table. It's late, he eats alone, but Janet sits with him, the new baby (MARK) asleep in her ar

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Rick had a nice time playing with little Ed next door... the White’s boy? They seem like nice folks. It's not oppressive, like after Karen died, but Neil’s distant. Maybe he is upset about the backup assignment?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Neil?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Sorry... There was this lecture on orbital mechanics. rendezvous with the thrust, you wind up because it puts you orbit. You need to and drop to a lower up. It’s backwards About how to Agena? If you going slower in a higher reduce thrust orbit to catch from what you learn as a pilot but if you work the math, it follows. It’s kinda neat.  33. Janet reacts. Trying not to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Well, it is.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure that’s how all the other guys feel. Neil smiles. Then chuckles, RELAXING. A nice, shared moment... atypical these days. Off Janet, ENJOYING it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil stands in boxers and a T-shirt, BRUSHING his teeth. Perfect little circles on each tooth. His mind elsewhere. Janet, in a nightgown, slips up behind him. Her hand reac around his stomach... then DOWN into his boxers. At first, Neil doesn’t notice. Then his mind and brush SL His eyes TICK to Janet in the mirror. CONSIDERING. Janet looks up at him. Insistent. A beat, then Neil turns, kissing her. As he pulls at her blouse, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Quiet. The windows open, a breeze plays on the drap moving over Janet and Neil, NAKED on the bed. We hear a CRACKLING in the b/g... and Janet stirs. She sits up, sle Her expression CLOUDS. She nudges Neil, softly. Then HARD

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Do you smell that? Neil sits up, groggy. Half awake, still processing, he ge out of bed, tosses on his boxers and heads down the hall. Janet waits. A beat, then SMOKE CURLS IN through the door Janet's eyes WIDEN as she hears Neil from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Call the fire department. Janet, stunned, reaches for the phone as we PUSH INTO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil runs down the HALLWAY, the roof IN FLAMES. Neil coug pushes through the smoke, pausing at the door to...  34. RICK’S ROOM. Rick sits up in bed. Disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Follow your mother outside. Rick nods and Neil moves on down the hall, HUSTLING INTO THE NURSERY. FILLED with smoke, the baby CRYING in the cr Neil grabs the baby, covers him in a blanket and RUNS OUT hurrying down the HALL into... THE FAMILY ROOM. All smoke and fire, we can’t even see Ne We hear him COUGH, STRUGGLING to breathe... ...then find him as he PUSHES THROUGH the back door into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil holds the baby, GASPING for breath, eyes TICKING... ...to ED WHITE, rushing across his yard to help... ...to the TERRIFYING BLAZE already engulfing most of the ...to JANET, standing there, staring. Lost. And ALONE. Neil PROCESSES, rushing to Janet and handing her the baby

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Ricky... Neil’s already on it, already turning back towards the ho when... A SECTION OF THE ROOF COLLAPSES. Janet turns WHITE. Neil quickly grabs a wet towel off the clothes line, covers his face and RUNS BACK INTO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls of THE FAMILY ROOM now GLOWING RED. Glass windo CRACK, the smoke forcing Neil onto hands and knees. HOLD ON Neil as he CRAWLS, groping his way into THE HALL, towel tight on his face, walls IN FLAMES around him. We f the heat as Neil INCHES along, eyes FIXED on a FARAWAY DO PUSH IN on Neil as the roar of the fire FADES and we hear FAMILIAR UNNERVING WHINE of Karen’s Cobalt Machine... Neil blocks it out, reaching the door and pushing it open Neil peers into RICK’S ROOM. Smoke and fire everywhere. Neil's eyes TICK across the room, scanning for Rick.  35. PUSH IN on his eyes, on something we haven't seen... FEAR The ODD WHINE SCREAMS above the din and Neil FREEZES, the thought of yet another loss creeping in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-until another SOUND pierces through. Faint at first, then LOUDER. A child’s whimper. Neil's ey DART to... Rick, TERRIFIED, hiding under his bed. Neil LU forward, scoops Rick up, wrapping him in the towel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as the fire seems to EBB. Neil confused, turns. And sp ED, through the window, hosing down the roof. The fire ROARS. Neil snaps to, RUSHES through THE HALL in THE FAMILY ROOM. ENGULFED AGAIN by smoke, he FALTERS... t holds Rick for dear life and CHARGES through the door int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil carries Rick out, pulls off the towel and looks at h

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You need to listen to what I say. It’s stark. ANGRY. Rick starts to CRY... as Janet rushes over, RELIEVED. She takes Rick and Neil moves towards the VOLUNTEER FIREMEN pouring out of the small FIRE TRUCK... ...-but Neil starts to WHEEZE. He has to pause, bending o STRUGGLING to catch his breath just as... THE REST OF THE ROOF COLLAPSES. Ed and the firemen are fo back. Janet reacts, EYES WIDE... but Neil just stares at blaze, at what's left of the house. EMOTIONLESS. Janet reaches for Neil, but he’s already moving towards E

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Fire's heading towards the garage, help me get the cars out? Ed follows Neil to the garage... leaving Janet with the k Alone. Watching her house burn to the ground. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A birds-eye view of the house... now wet, black RUBBLE an DYING EMBERS, smoke still reaching skyward. Neil picks through the wreckage as we PULL BACK into --  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the window, Janet holds the baby and a CHARRED WEDDING ALBUM. She looks down at a half destroyed PHOTO, Neil ina tuxedo. BEAMING. Lighter than we’ve ever seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet glances out the window, at what’s left of her house a very different Neil picking through the rubble. She FIGHTS to contain her emotions.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: We can put Rick in with Ed Jr. If this is big enough for you all? Janet pulls herself together, closing the album and turni Pat, who’s walked in with sheets and towels.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Of course. Deke is already working on finding us a rental, so it shouldn’t be too long.

dialogues.speaker: PAT WHITE
dialogues.text: Hush. It’ll be nice to have a few more voices ‘round the house. Not like Ed's ever home. Janet smiles, appreciative as a doorbell RINGS. CUT TO -- INT. FOYER, ED & PAT WHITE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed opens the door, finds Elliot and his wife MARILYN SEE, Marilyn holds a brisket; Elliot, his baby son and a bag. Elliot and Ed aren’t that friendly; it’s a bit AWKWARD.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: We heard Neil and Janet were-- JANET Marilyn, Elliot? Pat and Janet walk in. Marilyn holds out the brisket.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: It was the least we could do.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: And the girls insisted on sending some of their things. He holds out a bag of Barbie dolls. Janet laughs, touched  37.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Where’s Neil?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: He’s still over at the house.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I thought we got everything.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: You did. Off Ed, CONFUSED, CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil in the rubble with a FIRE INSPECTOR, 50s, nonchalant

dialogues.speaker: FIRE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Probably a short in the wiring. I‘ll write it up, send it over to the insurance company. The inspector starts to go, but Neil doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Fire came from the family room, we'd just replaced the ceiling panels...

dialogues.speaker: FIRE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: I’m sure they'll cover it, Mr. Armstrong. But Neil takes out a logbook and kneels, SCANNING the rub The inspector STARES and we...

dialogues.speaker: ED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ...the hell? PULL BACK to find Ed and Elliot at the edge of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Uh, he’s trying to -- ~ ED I know what he’s doing. Ed shakes his head. A beat, then he has an idea.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Let’s take a ride. They head off and we TIME CUT TO --  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunset. Wide on the house. Against the setting sun, the SILHOUETTE of a man... Neil inspecting the rubble. TIRELE A beat, then we see Neil bend down... ANGLE ON a BLACKENED BRACELET amidst ruined keepsakes in rubble. Neil wipes it off. KAR... the rest unreadable. CLOSE ON Neil’s eyes -- a HINT of emotion. Then he stands MOVING ON. Inching over the collapsed roof, looking for something else. And then bending down again...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Looks like it started here, probably was one of the paneling nails.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: So we’re good? The exhausted inspector walks over, wiping his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yep. We just have to find the nail. The inspector, EXASPERATED, stares as Neil digs into the

dialogues.speaker: ED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Neil! Ed’s in the yard with Elliot, holding the bag. He waves N over. A beat, then Neil joins them. Ed holds out the bag.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Present. Neil, confused, takes the bag. He opens it, pulls out a b new ‘IONIZATION CHAMBER SMOKE DETECTOR.’

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Smoke enters the chamber, it disrupts the current, thing screams like a son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: He got one for every house in the development. A beat. Neil looks up at Ed, SURPRISED. And GRATEFUL.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: How ‘bout a break?  INT. DINING ROOM, ED & PAT WHITE’S HOUSE - NIGHT
The three couples sit eating, kids playing in the family Janet's had a few glasses of wine.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine how frightening it must have been, waking up like that.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It would’ve been worse if I hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Well, sure. But you’re just handling this so well. Both of you. She smiles at Neil. He nods, awkward. Neil blinks,

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: At this point it’s just an inconvenience. Time spent on things which aren’t very productive. Like getting into another house.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure it’ll take up a lot of your time. SURPRISED. Elliot laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: (to Pat and Marilyn) Do you think this is how the cosmonauts treat their wives?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s how the female cosmonauts treat their husbands.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: No, I think we’ve hit on something. Maybe this is the problem.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: No female astronauts?  40.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Why do you think we're behind?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: We're not behind.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Right. The Russians are sending women up in space and I can’t even attend a launch at the Cape.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN JANET
dialogues.text: Really? What?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: No wives at the Cape. I asked about Ed’s flight, that’s what Deke said.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: It’s NASA policy.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: ‘Cause God forbid there’s a photo of me reacting if the rocket explodes. This is starting to get uncomfortable. Honey -- They turn to

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Deke and Chris just don’t want any distractions.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: From what I understand, there are all sorts of distractions.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Don’t honey me.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: This reminds me of a story. Neil, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: A fella I know made plans to play golf on his wedding anniversary. His wife got very upset. They had a spat, as couples do. She accused him of loving golf more than her. And the fella, well, he shrugged. (acting it) “I love you more than tennis."  41. A beat. It’s not particularly funny, but from Neil it’s surprising. And hilarious. The table bursts out laughing. EXT. ED WHITE’S HOUSE - NIGHT WIDE ON the yard. The house cozy, the windows casting war light, the yard dotted with fireflies. And then over the crickets, we hear faint STATIC. And chatter... in RUSSIAN PAN UP to the stars above. HOLD ON them as the Comms cont Chilling, spooky. And as we wonder what it means, PRELAP

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: I’m on the lookout for Dr. Zin. EXT. PORCH, WHITE’S HOUSE - NIGHT CLOSE ON Rick crouching by the porch with a walkie talkie

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (INTO WALKIE)
dialogues.text: I’m on the lookout for Dr. ED JR (OVER WALKIE) Zin. Copy? Roger, I’m flying to you. Nearby, Neil watches Rick, CALM. Elliot holds up a SEXTAN

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: Vega, Rigel. 8 degrees. Check me? Neil nods, takes Elliot’s sextant. Surveys the two stars.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yes. 8 degree angle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: You want to do Antares and Nunki? Neil nods, takes a reading. Ed walks outside with beers. sees Neil with the sextant and SHOOTS a look at Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: We head to Morehead on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) So why not waste a Saturday night. Neil ignores him, keeps at it. Elliot looks over at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT
dialogues.text: You've been down there, right?  42.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: To Morehead? Yeah. It’s cool, they shift star positions to mimic an off course craft. Bitch of a sim, but it’s how Cooper aligned Faith 7 when his navigation controls failed.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Good thing to know, I guess. Ed looks at Neil. Then chuckles, good-natured. Elliot doe too. And Neil smiles, a bit surprised at the BOND FORMING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat and Jan do dishes; Ed, Neil and Elliot in the window. Marilyn sits on the couch in the b/g with her youngest.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Your husband has a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: A little corny.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I never would have guessed.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I'm a bit surprised myself. A phone RINGS. Pat goes to get it, but we HOLD ON Jan, watching Neil with the others.

dialogues.speaker: PAT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ed? Deke’s on the phone. Ed hustles in. Neil follows behind, notices Janet’s stare As Ed picks up the phone, Neil drifts over to her.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just looking at you. She’s warm. Neil smiles, a bit mystified.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ..-Leonov is tethered to Voshkod 2, but nothing separates him from space other than his pressure suit... Neil turns. Ed’s flipped on the TV. Neil’s smile FADES as sees B&W FOOTAGE of A _COSMONAUT FLOATING OVER EARTH.  43. Neil tightens. The camera ominously PUSHES IN on the TV..

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: .--a pressure suit we’re told was designed for the lunar surface. This is, of course, mankind’s first E.V.A., or Extra-Vehicular Activity. BANG! Ed SLAMS his fist against the wall in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Shit. A beat, then Ed grabs his bag. Neil shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: They’ve added another mission objective to Gemini 4. Ed heads out the door but we HOLD ON Neil, PUSHING IN ON as the RUSSIAN COMMS on TV get LOUDER and we -- FADE OUT. OVER BLACK we hear the sound of U.S. COMMS --

dialogues.speaker: ED, (PRELAP, COMMS)
dialogues.text: Am I in your view, Jimbo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER SCREEN. Bé&w footage. An ASTRONAUT floats in spac

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: You’re right in front, Ed. REVERSE to Neil and Elliot, watching RAPT, as we realize floating astronaut is Ed. Gemini IV, Mission Day 1 June 3, 1965 Welcome to MISSION CONTROL, the latest, greatest tech of PUSH BUTTONS, ROTARY PHONES. Monitors of NUMBERS, STATIC on the big screens, a scrolling STYLUS tracking the capsu

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: This is the greatest experience I’ve... it’s just tremendous. Neil SMILES at Elliot as Deke enters with a group of men.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, Neil Armstrong and Elliot See, our backups on Gemini Five. (to Neil, Elliot) These are the fourteen newbies. Keep an eye on them, would you? As Deke heads off, Elliot notices a NEWBIE holding court.

dialogues.speaker: NEWBIE, (BUZZ)
dialogues.text: Ed and I were stationed together in Germany. He called me a few days ago to ask if I had tips for him based on my doctorate. I found that amusing, of course. I only went to MIT on his recommendation. Neil glances over at BUZZ ALDRIN, 33. Smart, arrogant, TO DEAF; he clearly annoys the others. And the flight direct

dialogues.speaker: KRAFT
dialogues.text: Cut the chatter. The room quiets. Kraft nods to CAPCOM GUS GRISSOM, 39, gr

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, Houston Cap Com, ED (COMMS) let’s bring Ed in now. Right now I’m standing on my head, I’m looking down on...

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, do you read me? ED (COMMS) My golly, I’m looking right in the bay there! Ed_and Jim clearly don’t hear Gus.

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, Houston; Gemini 4 -- JIM (COMMS) Ed, I’m gonna PUSH-TO-TALK, see what the Flight Director has to say. Gus, any message?

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Have Ed get his ass back in! EECOM ENGINEER 45 seconds to Loss of Signal. Kraft glances at EECOM. Neil catches it, notes his CONCER

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: They want you back now, Ed. ED (COMMS) I’m trying to get a picture of the spacecraft.  45.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: No, back in. Come on. ED (COMMS) .-.Saddest moment of my life.

dialogues.speaker: EECOM ENGINEER
dialogues.text: 30 seconds to Bermuda LOS. The video feed BREAKS UP. A long, silent beat.

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: 20 seconds to LOS, are you JIM (COMMS) getting him back in? Jim -- He’s having some trouble getting into the space craft.

dialogues.speaker: EECOM ENGINEER FLIGHT SURGEON
dialogues.text: 10 seconds -- Pilot’s heart rate is spiking. He’s up to 180 bps. Shit. Neil watches INTENT. The whole room looks concerned

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, give me a status. JIM (COMMS) Is he getting back in, Jim? Listen, we’re kinda busy! If you don't have something for us, wait a couple -- The audio turns to STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: EECOM ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Loss of Signal. KRAFT Switch to UHF. The EECOM engineer hits a switch; the static turns to SIL

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, Houston Cap Com. Gemini 4, give me your status. CLOSE ON Neil and Elliot as they wait, the TENSION PALPAB All the newbies, even Buzz, STARE. The silence is DEAFENI PUSH IN on Neil, eyes TICKING from screen to console. A b

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, do you -- ...that was something. That was the most natural feeling. Neil RELAXES. We hear more voices over comms.

dialogues.speaker: CARNAVON CAP COM, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Gemini 4, Carnavon Cap Com. JIM (COMMS) Hello Carnavon. We are back inside the spacecraft. We are repressurized to 5 PSI...  46. As the room lets out a collective breath, CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. Gus, exhausted, sits listening to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: .--then with Jim pulling hard as he could and me pulling down as best I could, we forced me down into my seat and got the hatch closed. PAN TO Neil, standing beside Gus. Listening, RAPT.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: I’m just glad we didn’t have to make a re-entry with the hatch open.

dialogues.speaker: GRISSOM, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Us too, Ed. (to Neil, sotto) Hold the fort, I gotta use the can. Gus slips away. The flight surgeon approaches with a NOTE

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: But there was no disorientation whatsoever. I was using my tether, actually walking on the spacecraft.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: (off the note) Ed, the doc wants the sleep period changed to let you get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Armstrong? Is that Neil?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yes. He’d like you to go ED (COMMS) four hours -- Have you seen Pat? Did she and the kids hear the EVA?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: ..-uh, yeah. Jan said they listened on the squawk box.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s terrific. Tell them not to worry, I’m dandy. Neil smiles, DISTRACTED from the task at hand. He almost seems bemused by Ed’s warmth towards him, by the STRENGTH their connection... Neil seems as HUMAN as we've ever see  47.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I’1l tell them. It sounds great, Ed. Like... it’s really something.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Sure as hell is. Wait ‘til you get up here. You’ll flip. A NICE MOMENT.. ‘til Neil sees the doc GLARING.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I bet. Listen, the doc would really like if you could get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Okay. I’l1l give it a try. But just you wait, you won’t be able to sleep either. Not with this view. Off Neil --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide on a LARGE WINDOWLESS STRUCTURE, lit up against the night. A sign, block letters: Mission Control Center. FIND Neil. Heading across the parking lot, lost in though But as he reaches the car... he PAUSES. And looks up... A sky of stars. We know Ed’s up there, in orbit, but it’s warmth or wonder in Neil’s eyes. It’s something else... .-- YEARNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful morning. GEMINI-TITAN V steaming on the pad.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Push-To-Talk Comm check. KSC CAPCOM (COMMS) Commander push-to-talk -- Yes, we read you, Neil. We’re at T minus 2 hours. PUSH IN CLOSER to the white room level, just outside the capsule. Men in flight suits prep for launch. Gemini V, Pre-Launch August 21, 1965 Holy shit, are Neil and Elliot about to head into space? Just as we think they are, we PUSH INTO the capsule... to the two of them not in spacesuits, but in routine FLIGHT  48.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Pilot Push-To-Talk. GORDO COOPER (COMMS) Read you loud and clear. Elliot looks up, sees GORDO COOPER, 38, brusque, and Pete Conrad. In SPACESUITS.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONRAD, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: We got it, fellas. Neil and Elliot (the backups) step out, awkwardly helping Cooper and Conrad into the small capsule. As Neil buckles Pete, he eyes the Gemini 5 Patch on his arm. 8 DAYS OR BU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, Elliot ride down the side of the Titan rocket. And it’s more substantial than the Mercury Atlas, but at 100 it still feels puny compared to the Apollo we all know.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: Think the docs know what eight days in space'll do to those guys?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Might kill both of them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: It'd be quieter ‘round here.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Sounds nice. Elliot SMILES. Then Neil does. Clearly, they’re even clos The elevator stops and Neil and Elliot walk out onto -- THE LAUNCH PAD. They move to confer with Deke and a few engineers, Elliot shouting over the steaming rocket...

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE
dialogues.text: System checks look good, hydrogen’s steady at 101.5... As Elliot continues, Deke pulls Neil aside. He nods at th Gemini capsule just ten stories up...

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: Those two make it back, we’ll be one up on the Soviets. Not much of a lead, but one we don’t want to lose. (then) I’m putting you in command of Gemini 8. Like 6 and 7, rendezvous and docking will be your primary goal.  Neil pauses, 49.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Elliot and I will start training.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna pair you with Dave Scott. We've got a pretty strenuous E.V.A. planned for eight, Dave’s a horse. Conrad will serve as your backup. looks back at Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: DEKE
dialogues.text: We'll put that brain of his to work. But these missions are key to Apollo. We wanna beat Brezhnev to the moon, we gotta be ready soon as Werner has the rocket to take us. Off Neil, processing this, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE SCOTT, 35, very good looking and very enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE SCOTT
dialogues.text: Pretty exciting mission, huh? FIND Neil sitting beside Dave as a MECHANICAL ARM slowly their Gemini trainer away from a mock Agena docking satel

dialogues.speaker: DAVE SCOTT
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s the whole ball of wax, everything we need for Apollo. E.V.A., rendezvous, we'll be one of the first to dock with the Agena... Neil remains focused on a Gemini instrument chart, reachi for instruments without looking up, going over their posi

dialogues.speaker: DAVE SCOTT
dialogues.text: Can’t ask for a better assignment. Heck, I don’t think I’ve been this jazzed since they asked me to swim Varsity as a freshman in High --

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Could you be quiet? Dave, surprised, eyes Neil, who keeps studying the Gemini instruments... the slightest hint of ANNOYANCE on his fac

dialogues.speaker: DAVE SCOTT
dialogues.text: Didn't you do this already? On 5?  50. Neil doesn’t respond. Dave, now annoyed himself, opens hi manual. For a moment, they work in silence. And off Neil, perhaps wishing it were Elliot beside him, PRELAP --

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE, (PRELAP, COMMS)
dialogues.text: NASA 7 descending through 2,000 feet, permission to approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot sits in front, managing the T-38 descent for landi Some light turbulence, clouds all around. ZERO VISIBILITY

dialogues.speaker: ELLINGTON TOWER, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Nasa 7, you’re cleared for approach, come on down outta ELLIOT SEE (INTO COMMS) that soup... Roger that. Coming in. As Elliot guides the plane down, he chats with his co-pil the rear cockpit, CHARLIE BASSETT, 34, all American.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: How long we here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: A while. Deke wants the new Agena ready for March.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT
dialogues.text: So 8’d get the first shot? Sets Neil and Dave up good for Apollo. Elliot doesn’t say anything. The slightest hint of ENVY.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Thank god I didn’t pull that assignment. Poor Dave, Armstrong's gonna run him ragged.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: (smiles) That is an upside to training with Neil. Next assignment’s a cakewalk. Bassett LAUGHS as they drop through 500 feet, breaking th clouds. Elliot visually clocks his position... -.-and instantly sees HE’S SHORT.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: We’re low and slow, Elliot...  51.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOT SEE, (INTO COMMS)
dialogues.text: Damn radar. (a quick decision) I don’t wanna get lost in the clouds again, I’m just gonna go round. He hits the afterburners, pulls the stick to make a low t

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Elliot... We hear the ANXIETY in Bassett's voice as Elliot sees...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BASSETT, (COMMS)
dialogues.text: Pull up. Elliot... ELLIOT SEE Dammit... Dammit... Elliot YANKS up on the stick, but it’s not enough. As the SPEED towards the building ELLIOT'S EYES WIDEN and we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEIL. Quiet. Studying rendezvous and docking calculations a notebook, his dinner off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Are you excited? REVEAL Janet, Rick and Mark (now 8 and 4) also at the tab eating dinner. It's raining hard out, real Texas thunder.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Honey, let your father eat NEIL his -- Excited about what? Neil looks at Rick. Janet watches, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That you might be first. To dock.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Well, you have to prepare for all sorts of eventualities when you do something first. There’s much greater risk of failure. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil returns 52.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fact is, the only reason we might be first is cause the first Agena exploded after separation and it’s going to take a few months to build the new one. to his notebook, oblivious to WIDE-EYED Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: A ship exploded?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It was just a satellite, honey. No one was hurt. Before Jan can say more we hear a KNOCK... Neil doesn’t e notice. Janet, used to this, gets up, walks to door... -.-and opens it. Ed’s on the porch. SOAKED from the rain.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Hey. Jan, can I speak to him?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Uh, sure. You want to come in?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: No. Janet sees something in his eyes. Knows better than to as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil walks out onto the porch. Neil stops.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
